questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the physician because of persistent reddening of the face for the past 3 months. During this period, he has also had difficulty concentrating at work and has experienced generalized fatigue. He has fallen asleep multiple times during important meetings. His mother has rheumatoid arthritis. He has hypertension and asthma. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 28 years and drinks one alcoholic beverage per day. Medications include enalapril and a salbutamol inhaler. He is 170 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 88 kg (194 lb); BMI is 30 kg/m2. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 145/85 mm Hg. Physical examination shows erythema of the face that is especially pronounced around the cheeks, nose, and ears. His neck appears short and wide. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's facial discoloration?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient presents with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), in which nighttime obstruction of the upper airways (e.g., due to obesity) leads to apneic episodes, hypoxia, and poor quality of sleep. Sleep deprivation causes daytime sleepiness and impaired concentration, while hypoxia triggers erythropoietin secretion and increased production of RBCs, resulting in plethora, a characteristic red discoloration of the face. Chronic hypoxia can also trigger a sympathetic response, which would explain this patient's hypertension.

B) INCORRECT:

Increased serotonin levels in individuals who are not taking serotonergic medications (e.g., SSRIs) indicate carcinoid syndrome. This condition is caused by neuroendocrine tumors that cause diarrhea, abdominal cramps, asthma-like attacks, and facial flushing. Although this patient has a history of asthma and facial flushing, the flushing caused by carcinoid syndrome lasts for about 30 minutes, unlike the permanent erythema seen here. Moreover, the lack of gastrointestinal symptoms makes carcinoid syndrome unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

A delayed-type hypersensitivity reaction can cause several conditions, such as allergic contact dermatitis or polymorphous light eruption (PLE). PLE should be considered in individuals with an outbreak of pruritic skin lesions following exposure to intense sunlight (especially in the spring or summer). While PLE can manifest as facial erythema, this diagnosis is unlikely in a patient without a history of recent travel or outdoor activities and further skin lesions on areas of the body exposed to the sun (e.g., neck, forearms). Furthermore, both allergic contact dermatitis and PLE typically manifest with pruritus.
Image Description:

Erythematous papules and lesions with irregular borders are visible on the cheeks and forehead.

D) INCORRECT:

An immune response to Malassezia furfur is the cause of tinea versicolor, a superficial yeast infection of the skin that manifests with sharply demarcated, pruritic lesions on the trunk and chest. The lesions become apparent as strongly hypopigmented areas after exposure to sunlight. This patient's nonpruritic erythema of the face and pronounced fatigue cannot be explained by a Malassezia infection.
Image Description:

Back of a patient

Multiple round, well-demarcated, confluent, depigmented macules are visible.

This finding indicates pityriasis versicolor, which is caused by Malassezia species.

E) INCORRECT:

Antibody-mediated vasculopathy is a feature of dermatomyositis. Typical cutaneous manifestations of dermatomyositis include Gottron papules, photosensitive skin lesions (e.g., erythema of the neck), and a heliotrope rash. While dermatomyositis can also manifest with midfacial erythema, the diagnosis is unlikely in the absence of further typical findings (e.g., muscle weakness, myalgia).
Image Description:

Erythematous papules are visible on the dorsal aspect of the interphalangeal and metacarpophalangeal joints. This is the typical localization of Gottron papules, which are pathognomonic of dermatomyositis.

Periungual erythema is also visible.

F) INCORRECT:

Increased cortisol levels are a diagnostic finding in individuals with Cushing syndrome. This patient presents with several symptoms that could suggest hypercortisolism, including hypertension, obesity, a thick neck, and facial erythema. However, since other typical features are not present (e.g., fragile skin, muscle atrophy) and Cushing syndrome is not associated with the degree of fatigue this patient is experiencing, another diagnosis is more likely.
Image Description:

Multiple vertical, approx. 2-cm wide, violaceous striae are visible along the lateral and ventral thorax of this 32-year-old, overweight man.

This constellation of features suggests Cushing syndrome.
questions.hint: Increased daytime sleepiness, impaired concentration, and enlarged neck circumference due to overweight make obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) a likely diagnosis. Male sex, smoking, and alcohol consumption are additional risk factors for OSA.

A 48-year-old man comes to the physician because of difficulty concentrating at work and generalized fatigue for the past 5 months. During this period, he has often fallen asleep while watching his favorite TV show. His wife reports that he snores loudly and often stops breathing for a few seconds while asleep. He has hypertension treated with metoprolol. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years. He is 168 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 87 kg (192 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m2. questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

High pH and decreased pCO2 with normal pO2, chloride, and HCO3 are consistent with respiratory alkalosis, which results from hyperventilation (e.g., during a panic attack). OSA causes hypoventilation during sleep.

B) CORRECT:

Low pH, elevated pCO2 with normal bicarbonate and chloride concentrations are consistent with acute respiratory acidosis. In patients with OSA, upper airway obstruction during sleep causes alveolar hypoventilation and subsequent retention of CO2, which leads to respiratory acidosis. In the initial phase of acidosis, only minimal metabolic compensation from the rapid action of buffers in the blood is expected. Repeated episodes of CO2 retention are eventually compensated for by renal retention of bicarbonate and decreased chloride reabsorption. In acute respiratory acidosis, for every 10 mm Hg increase in pCO2 above 40 mm Hg, the HCO3- concentration increases by 1 mEq/L from 24 mEq/L with an expected variability of +/- 3 mEq/L. While pO2 decreases during apneic episodes, hypoxia causes the individual to wake up, restoring oxygenation to normal or near-normal levels. If arterial blood gas analysis is performed when the patient is not experiencing apneic episodes, arterial blood gas analysis results may be normal.

Chronic CO2 retention can lead to persistent renal retention of bicarbonate, which may result in compensatory metabolic alkalosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Borderline low pH, elevated pCO2, elevated serum bicarbonate concentration, and decreased serum chloride concentration are consistent with compensated respiratory acidosis. Because OSA causes alveolar hypoventilation, respiratory acidosis due to CO2 retention is expected. In primary respiratory disorders, complete metabolic compensation takes approximately 2–5 days. This patient's diurnal arterial blood gas analysis is normal; therefore, complete metabolic compensation at night is unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Low pH, normal pCO2, decreased serum bicarbonate concentration, and increased serum chloride concentration are consistent with normal anion gap metabolic acidosis with appropriate respiratory compensation (based on the Winter formula). This set of findings is seen in patients with renal tubular acidosis or chronic kidney disease but not in those with OSA.

E) INCORRECT:

Normal pH, decreased pCO2, decreased serum bicarbonate concentration, and normal serum chloride levels are consistent with high anion gap metabolic acidosis. According to the Winter formula, the expected value for pCO2 given a serum bicarbonate concentration of 18 mEq/L is 35 ± 2 mm Hg, which is much higher than the measured value of 26 mEq/L and indicates the additional presence of respiratory alkalosis. This combination of metabolic acidosis and respiratory alkalosis is a typical finding in patients with salicylate toxicity or septic shock but not in those with OSA.
questions.hint: Daytime sleepiness, impaired concentration, and snoring with apneic episodes suggest obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), for which obesity is a risk factor.

questions.text:
A 37-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 10-month history of excessive daytime sleepiness and fatigue. She says she has difficulty concentrating and has fallen asleep at work on numerous occasions. She also reports having frequent headaches during the day. She has no difficulty falling asleep at night, but wakes up gasping for breath at least once. She has always snored loudly and began using an oral device to decrease her snoring a year ago. She has occasional lower back pain, for which she takes tramadol tablets 1–2 times per week. She also began taking one rabeprazole tablet daily 3 weeks ago. She does not smoke. She is 175 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 119 kg (262 lb); BMI is 39 kg/m2. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical and neurologic examinations show no other abnormalities. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows:


pH
7.35


PCO2
51 mm Hg


PO2

64 mm Hg


HCO3-

29 mEq/L


O2 saturation
92%


An x-ray of the chest and ECG show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's blood gas abnormalities?

choices.text: Apneic episodes with obstructed upper airways
Reduced oxygen carrying capacity of blood
Skeletal abnormality of the chest wall

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Apnea due to obstructed upper airways is characteristic of obstructive sleep apnea (OSA). This patient's history and clinical features are consistent with OSA, in which obstruction to the upper airways results in apneic episodes that in turn cause hypercapnia and respiratory acidosis on arterial blood gas analysis. However, these abnormalities are typically absent when the patient is awake, which is not the case here.

B) INCORRECT:

Central respiratory depression due to deceleration of rhythmic impulses from the respiratory center in the CNS can occur secondary to opioid overdose. The resulting hypoventilation would cause abnormalities in arterial blood gas analysis similar to those seen in this patient, who is taking tramadol. However, tramadol is generally considered safer than most opioids with regard to respiratory depression and this patient's occasional tramadol use is not enough to cause respiratory depression. In this obese patient, another diagnosis is more likely.

C) INCORRECT:

Reduced oxygen carrying capacity of the blood is characteristic of anemia, which is an important differential diagnosis in patients with chronic fatigue and nonspecific symptoms. However, other features such as pallor and palpitations would be expected. Furthermore, arterial blood gas analysis in this patient shows hypercapnia and respiratory acidosis, which is not a finding associated with anemia.

D) INCORRECT:

Skeletal abnormalities of the chest wall (e.g., kyphoscoliosis, pectus excavatum) can restrict respiratory excursion, resulting in hypoventilation and arterial blood gas findings similar to those seen in this patient. However, chest wall abnormalities that would be severe enough to cause such symptoms would be obvious on clinical examination and/or on imaging.

E) INCORRECT:

Chronic inflammatory airflow limitation is the mechanism of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). The main findings are chronic cough with expectoration, dyspnea, early inspiratory coarse crackles, and wheezing, as well as a prolonged expiratory phase and decreased breath sounds. Arterial blood gas analysis will show findings similar to what is seen in this patient: decreased pO2 and daytime hypercapnia due to air trapping as a result of expiratory collapse of small airways. However, chest x-ray would likely show signs of hyperinflation (e.g., horizontal ribs and widened intercostal spaces, increased anteroposterior diameter, flattened diaphragm). Furthermore, COPD predominantly affects patients with a history of smoking, making it unlikely in this nonsmoker.

F) INCORRECT:

Thickening of alveolar membranes with impaired gas exchange is characteristic of interstitial lung disease, which manifests with exertional dyspnea that progresses to dyspnea at rest, persistent nonproductive cough, and fatigue. Arterial blood gas analysis will show low partial oxygen pressure and respiratory acidosis due to impaired gas exchange, but only in the late stages of disease. Given the absence of pulmonary symptoms, this patient is unlikely to have advanced interstitial lung disease. Furthermore, chest x-ray in interstitial lung disease is likely to show an increase in reticular opacities, indicating fibrosis, whereas this patient's x-ray findings are normal.

G) CORRECT:

Obesity hypoventilation syndrome (OHS) is characterized by awake alveolar hypoventilation resulting in daytime hypercapnia and respiratory acidosis. Metabolic compensation (elevated HCO3-) is usually also present and indicates that the hypercapnia and respiratory acidosis is chronic. Obesity reduces inspiratory muscle strength and restricts respiratory excursions, resulting in alveolar hypoventilation. Moreover, obesity is associated with increased production of CO2 as a result of the larger body surface area, further contributing to hypercapnia. OHS can be diagnosed in patients with BMI ≥ 30 kg/m2 with symptoms similar to OSA (excessive daytime sleepiness, restless sleep, snoring with apneic episodes) and evidence of daytime alveolar hypoventilation on arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis that cannot be otherwise explained.

90% of patients with OHS also have obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) and distinguishing the two conditions can be challenging because the risk factors and symptoms are very similar. The main difference between the two conditions is that the ABG abnormalities are diurnal in OHS and nocturnal in OSA.
questions.hint: This patient's condition is named after Charles Dickens's "Pickwick Papers,” which features a character named Joe who is notable for his obesity and tendency to fall asleep.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man comes to the physician for a 5-month history of progressive bilateral ankle swelling and shortness of breath on exertion. He can no longer walk up the stairs to his bedroom without taking a break. He also constantly feels tired during the day. His wife reports that he snores at night and that he sometimes chokes in his sleep. The patient has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years. He has a history of hypertension treated with enalapril. His pulse is 72/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 145/95 mm Hg. There is jugular venous distention. The lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. The extremities are warm and well perfused. There is 2+ lower extremity edema bilaterally. ECG shows right axis deviation. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Left ventricular hypertrophy can be caused by chronic hypertension and may result in left heart failure. Dysfunction of the left ventricle is a common cause of left heart failure, as it results in decreased cardiac output and backup of blood into the left ventricle. While left ventricular failure may lead to right ventricular dysfunction, signs of left ventricular dysfunction (e.g., orthopnea, pulmonary edema, cool extremities) are still expected. This patient, however, presents with signs of isolated right heart failure.

B) INCORRECT:

Ischemic heart disease may manifest with dyspnea on exertion and fatigue, and it is common in patients with hypertension and a long history of smoking. However, other findings expected in ischemic heart disease, such as episodes of retrosternal chest pain or pressure (angina) or evidence of myocardial ischemia on ECG (e.g., ST-segment abnormalities, T-wave inversion), are not seen here.

C) CORRECT:

Snoring, restless sleep (occasionally choking during sleep), and chronic fatigue are suggestive of obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), for which smoking is a risk factor. OSA causes hypoxia during apneic episodes, which leads to hypoxic pulmonary vasoconstriction. Severe and long-standing OSA causes a constant increase in pulmonary pressure, which can result in right ventricular dysfunction. Impaired function of the right ventricle due to pulmonary hypertension resulting from a primary disorder of the respiratory or pulmonary artery system is referred to as cor pulmonale.

D) INCORRECT:

Chronic kidney disease can be caused by chronic hypertension (hypertensive nephropathy) and may manifest with fatigue, bilateral ankle edema due to protein loss, and dyspnea due to fluid overload, which can result in pulmonary edema. However, in pulmonary edema, crackles are typically heard on pulmonary examination. Furthermore, hypertensive nephropathy results in left ventricular hypertrophy and left axis deviation.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients with lung cancer (i.e., pulmonary neoplasia) may also present with fatigue and shortness of breath. This patient's 25-year history of smoking puts him at risk of lung cancer. However, given the absence of cough, hemoptysis, or other constitutional or paraneoplastic symptoms, lung cancer is unlikely. Moreover, pulmonary neoplasia is unlikely to cause symptoms of right heart failure. This patient's history of snoring and nocturnal choking suggests another etiology of his right ventricular dysfunction.

F) INCORRECT:

Alveolar destruction is a finding in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), another common cause of pulmonary hypertension and cor pulmonale. COPD can manifest with dyspnea and pitting edema, and it is very likely to occur in patients with a long history of smoking. However, other findings typically expected in COPD, such as a chronic productive cough (lasting ≥ 3 months over 2 consecutive years) or signs of obstruction on lung auscultation (e.g., wheezing, decreased breath sounds), are not seen here. Moreover, this patient's history of snoring and choking at night makes another cause of his symptoms more likely.
questions.hint: The physical examination findings (bilateral ankle swelling, exertional dyspnea, increased jugular venous pressure) and right axis deviation on ECG suggest right ventricular dysfunction.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man comes to the physician because of intermittent throbbing headaches over the past year. The headaches are worse when he wakes up and are not accompanied by other symptoms. The patient also reports trouble concentrating on daily tasks at his office job. His wife recently started sleeping in their guest bedroom because “I just couldn't take it anymore. His sinusitis has been acting up at night and I was not able to catch any sleep.” The patient has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, chronic sinusitis, and an allergy to dust mites. Medications include enalapril, bisoprolol, and atorvastatin. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 14 years. His pulse is 72/min and blood pressure is 150/95 mm Hg. He is 178 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 120 kg (265 lb); BMI is 38 kg/m2. Neurologic examination is normal. Cardiac examination shows a normal S1 and S2 and no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. His skin is warm and well perfused. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's hypertension?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Low circulating free thyroxine levels, seen in hypothyroidism, could explain this patient's hypertension, impaired concentration, and obesity. However, he lacks other characteristic features of hypothyroidism, such as cold intolerance, constipation, hyporeflexia, bradycardia, and skin changes (e.g., cold, dry skin, myxedema, hair loss).

B) CORRECT:

The collapse of pharyngeal muscles during sleep leading to transient nocturnal upper airway obstruction is the main mechanism underlying obstructive sleep apnea (OSA). Typical features of this disease include nocturnal snoring, morning headaches, poor concentration, daytime sleepiness, fatigue, and depression. Nocturnal apneic episodes in individuals with OSA result in nocturnal hypercapnia, which, in turn, causes an increased sympathetic response that leads to secondary hypertension. Obesity, especially around the neck, is the most important risk factor for developing OSA, and weight loss will often improve symptoms.
Image Description:

Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) is the most common sleep-related breathing disorder and is typically associated with obesity, especially around the neck (short, wide “bull neck”). The relaxation and collapse of the pharyngeal muscles (e.g., tongue, uvula, soft palate) during sleep results in the obstruction of the upper airways. This obstruction causes multiple episodes of interrupted breathing (apnea and hypopnea events) as well as irregular snoring (due to soft-tissue vibrations caused by the obstructed airflow during respiration), gasping, or choking episodes.

C) INCORRECT:

Hypophyseal or pituitary adenomas can cause a mass effect leading to headaches. Secondary hypercortisolism due to increased ACTH secretion from a functional pituitary adenoma (Cushing disease) could also explain this patient's hypertension, poor concentration, and obesity. However, pituitary adenomas usually cause visual field defects (e.g., bitemporal hemianopsia), which are not reported on neurological examination. In addition, hyperpigmentation and cutaneous features of Cushing syndrome (e,g., thin skin, striae, buffalo hump) would be expected in patients with Cushing disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Pheochromocytoma, a usually benign tumor of the chromaffin cells in the adrenal gland, could explain this patient's hypertension and intermittent headaches. However, the headaches associated with pheochromocytoma are typically paroxysmal and accompanied by significant sweating, tachycardia, and pallor. Early morning headache, difficulty concentrating, and obesity suggest a different underlying cause for this patient's hypertension.

E) INCORRECT:

Primary hyperaldosteronism can manifest with treatment refractory hypertension and headaches. However, hyperaldosteronism would not explain this patient's difficulty concentrating or obesity. The presence of these features suggests a different diagnosis.

F) INCORRECT:

Low synaptic serotonin levels are associated with depression, which can manifest with weight gain, inability to concentrate, and chronic headache (e.g., migraine), but it would not cause hypertension.
questions.hint: A questionnaire is used to screen for this patient's condition and polysomnography is used to confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text: The patient undergoes polysomnography, which shows around 10 apneic episodes that cease on arousal, confirming a diagnosis of obstructive sleep apnea. The physician recommends therapy with a continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) device at night and counsels the patient on the importance of losing weight, maintaining proper sleep positioning, and avoidance of alcohol and medications that affect the central nervous system. At a follow-up visit one month later, the patient reports a sensation of claustrophobia while wearing the CPAP device's mask and refuses to adhere to the CPAP therapy. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the treatment of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In the adult population, enlargement of the uvula, soft palate, and retrolingual tissue are the primary causes of OSA and uvulopalatopharyngoplasty is a second-line treatment for moderate to severe OSA. Adenotonsillectomy is indicated for OSA caused by adenotonsillar hypertrophy, which is a cause of OSA primarily in children.

B) INCORRECT:

Nocturnal oxygen therapy can be used as an adjunctive treatment for certain patients with central sleep apnea (e.g., central sleep apnea related to heart failure) but is not used to treat OSA. A treatment that relieves obstruction in the upper airway is required for patients with OSA.

C) INCORRECT:

The glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) provides motor innervation only to the stylopharyngeus muscle, which dilates the nasopharynx during breathing. CN IX stimulation has no role in OSA treatment because OSA is primarily caused by obstruction at the level of the oropharynx rather than the nasopharynx. Instead, stimulation of the hypoglossal nerve (CN XII), which opens the oropharynx and lower pharyngeal airway by protruding and depressing the tongue, can be used as a second-line treatment for patients with moderate to severe OSA.

D) CORRECT:

Oral appliances and positional therapy devices are second-line treatment options for patients with mild to moderate OSA. A mandibular advancement device worn during sleep is the most commonly recommended oral appliance for OSA patients and works by maintaining an anterior-inferior mandibular advancement to prevent airway collapse. Positional therapy devices keep patients in a lateral as opposed to supine sleeping position. For patients with moderate to severe OSA, upper airway modification procedures (e.g., uvulopalatopharyngoplasty, maxillomandibular advancement surgery, radiofrequency ablation of oropharyngeal tissue, hypoglossal nerve stimulation) can be considered.
Image Description:

The device is worn during sleep to treat mild to moderate obstructive sleep apnea or primary snoring. It pushes the lower jaw forward, leading to a wider opening of the upper airway and preventing airway collapse.

E) INCORRECT:

Atomoxetine, which has noradrenergic effects that reduce upper airway collapsibility, has been proposed as a potential therapy for OSA. However, no pharmacological agent has yet been proven to be effective against OSA, so atomoxetine therapy would not be the most appropriate initial treatment.
questions.hint: Positive airway pressure (e.g., CPAP) is the first-line treatment for obstructive sleep apnea (OSA). If the patient is unable to tolerate positive airway pressure therapy, a second-line treatment for OSA should be considered. The occurence of 5–15 apneic or hypopneic episodes during sleep consistent with mild OSA.

questions.text: A 66-year old man comes to the physician because of fatigue for 6 months. He says that he wakes up every morning feeling tired. Most days of the week he feels sleepy during the day and often takes an afternoon nap for an hour. His wife says he snores in the middle of the night. He has a history of heart failure and atrial fibrillation. His medications include aspirin, atorvastatin, lisinopril, metoprolol, and warfarin. He drinks 1–2 glasses of wine daily with dinner; he does not smoke. He is 175 cm (5 ft 9 in) tall and weighs 96 kg (212 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m2. His pulse is 98/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 142/88 mm Hg. Examination of the oral cavity shows a low-lying palate. Cardiac examination shows an irregularly irregular rhythm and no murmurs. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An ENT evaluation for low-lying palate may eventually be helpful in treating this patient's OSA with upper airway surgery. It is not, however, the most appropriate next step in management, which should include confirmatory diagnostic testing and evaluation for more conservative treatment, such as continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP).

B) INCORRECT:

Overnight pulse oximetry can measure desaturation events, which commonly occur in patients with OSA. However, overnight pulse oximetry alone cannot confirm the diagnosis or guide management.

C) INCORRECT:

Home sleep apnea testing is appropriate for patients with suspected uncomplicated OSA. However, in patients with significant comorbidities (e.g., heart failure and atrial fibrillation), another step in management must be taken first.

D) CORRECT:

In-laboratory polysomnography is considered the gold-standard diagnostic test for OSA. Diagnostic polysomnography is preferred over home testing, particularly in patients with suspected complicated OSA, such as this patient with a history of heart failure and atrial fibrillation. Polysomnography typically shows apnea and hypopnea events, oxygen desaturation, arousal events on EEG, bradycardia, and fragmentation of sleep. Once OSA is diagnosed, additional polysomnography testing determines parameters for continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) treatment.

OSA has a strong association with cardiovascular disease, including hypertension and cardiac arrhythmias. In this patient, these comorbidities may be secondary to underlying OSA. Successful treatment of OSA can improve cardiovascular outcomes.

E) INCORRECT:

Echocardiography can demonstrate structural or functional cardiac defects. In this patient with known heart failure, poor sleep could also be caused by paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea due to nightly reabsorption of edema resulting from congestive heart failure. However, this patient's physical examination does not show lung crackles, lower extremity edema, or an S3 gallop, making heart failure exacerbation an unlikely diagnosis.
questions.hint: This patient with symptoms of daytime sleepiness and snoring likely has obstructive sleep apnea (OSA). Standardized questionnaires and third-party reports identify risk factors like the ones seen here, such as male sex, obesity, alcohol consumption, and a low-lying palate, which can impair respiratory flow.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man comes to the physician because of excessive daytime sleepiness for 5 months. He wakes up frequently at night, and his wife says his snoring has become louder. He is 180 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 104 kg (230 lb); his BMI is 33 kg/m2. His pulse is 80/min and his respiratory rate is 11/min. His jugular venous pressure is 7 cm H2O. He has 2+ pitting edema of the lower legs and ankles. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows a pH of 7.42 and a PCO2 of 41 mm Hg. An x-ray of the chest shows normal findings. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Increased medullary ventilatory responsiveness is involved in the pathogenesis of Cheyne-Stokes breathing in CNS disorders, in which a damaged respiratory center has an erratic respiratory drive only able to recognize relatively large increases in PCO2. These increases then trigger an overactive response that results in hyperventilation, causing PCO2 to fall, which leads back to a lack of activation of the respiratory center. The result is a period of apnea, which increases PCO2 again and starts the cycle anew. Cheyne-Stokes breathing is associated with central sleep apnea, a condition that occurs in CNS disorders and heart failure, neither of which are present here.

B) INCORRECT:

Impaired myocardial relaxation is one of the findings in patients with heart failure with preserved ejection fraction. These patients can have frequent nighttime awakenings, as this patient does, usually in the setting of shortness of breath (i.e., paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea). While heart failure would explain this patient's nighttime awakenings and lower extremity edema, it would also likely present with elevated JVP (> 8 cm H2O), cardiomegaly, and pulmonary edema on chest x-ray, none of which are seen here.

C) INCORRECT:

Decreased levels of hypocretin-1 are seen in narcolepsy, which could explain this patient's excessive daytime sleepiness and frequent nighttime awakenings. However, narcolepsy is not associated with snoring or obesity, as observed in this patient. Instead, narcolepsy often presents with cataplexy, sleep paralysis, and hypnagogic hallucinations.

D) CORRECT:

Intermittent collapse of the oropharynx leads to obstruction of the upper airways in obstructive sleep apnea (OSA). Patients with OSA have restless sleep interrupted by apneic episodes, which cause frequent awakening and eventual excessive daytime sleepiness, as seen here. Obesity, particularly around the neck, is the most important risk factor for OSA. Although OSA can eventually cause pulmonary hypertension and right heart failure, this patient's pitting edema is more likely due to his OSA and obesity, since both the jugular venous pressure and chest x-ray are normal.
Image Description:

Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) is the most common sleep-related breathing disorder and is typically associated with obesity, especially around the neck (short, wide “bull neck”). The relaxation and collapse of the pharyngeal muscles (e.g., tongue, uvula, soft palate) during sleep results in the obstruction of the upper airways. This obstruction causes multiple episodes of interrupted breathing (apnea and hypopnea events) as well as irregular snoring (due to soft-tissue vibrations caused by the obstructed airflow during respiration), gasping, or choking episodes.

E) INCORRECT:

Daytime alveolar hypoventilation occurs in obesity hypoventilation syndrome (OHS). OHS can manifest with daytime sleepiness in an obese patient, as seen here. However, OHS requires an ABG showing diurnal hypercapnia (PaCO2 > 45 mm Hg) for diagnosis, and this patient's ABG on room air shows a pH of 7.42 and a PCO2 of 41 mm Hg.
questions.hint: This patient's obesity and snoring are very suggestive of a specific diagnosis.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man comes to the physician for a 3-month history of progressive shortness of breath on exertion and tiredness throughout the day. His wife reports that he snores at night and that he sometimes chokes in his sleep. He has a history of hypertension treated with enalapril. His blood pressure is 149/96 mmHg. There is jugular venous distention and 2+ lower extremity edema bilaterally. The lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. An ECG shows right axis deviation. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Coronary artery disease may present with dyspnea on exertion and fatigue and is common in patients with hypertension, which this patient has. However, this patient has not reported episodes of retrosternal chest pain or pressure (angina), and the ECG does not show any evidence of myocardial ischemia (e.g., ST-segment abnormalities, T-wave inversion).

B) CORRECT:

This patient snores at night, occasionally chokes in his sleep, and is chronically fatigued. These findings suggest obstructive sleep apnea. OSA causes hypoxia during apneic episodes, which leads to hypoxic pulmonary vasoconstriction. Severe and long-standing OSA causes a constant increase in pulmonary pressure and results in right ventricular dysfunction. Impaired function of the right ventricle caused by pulmonary hypertension as the result of a primary disorder of the respiratory or pulmonary artery system is referred to as cor pulmonale.

C) INCORRECT:

Left ventricular hypertrophy can be caused by chronic hypertension and may result in left heart failure. Dysfunction of the left ventricle is a common cause of left heart failure, as it causes decreased cardiac output and backup of blood into the left ventricle. However, apart from dyspnea on exertion, this patient does not have features of left heart failure (e.g., orthopnea, pulmonary edema, cool extremities). Instead, he presents with signs of isolated right heart failure.

D) INCORRECT:

Alveolar destruction is a finding in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, another common cause of pulmonary hypertension and cor pulmonale. COPD can also manifest with dyspnea and pitting edema. However, this patient does not have a chronic productive cough (≥ 3 months over 2 consecutive years), has no signs of obstruction on lung auscultation (e.g., wheezing, decreased breath sounds), and has a history of snoring and choking at night. This makes another cause of his symptoms more likely.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients with hypertensive nephropathy may present with fatigue, bilateral ankle edema due to protein loss and dyspnea due to fluid overload, causing pulmonary edema. However, no crackles, which would be typical for pulmonary edema, were heard on this patient's pulmonary exam. Furthermore, hypertensive nephropathy would result in left ventricular hypertrophy and left axis deviation instead of right heart dysfunction.
questions.hint: Exertional dyspnea, bilateral ankle swelling, increased jugular venous pressure, and an ECG showing right axis deviation indicate right ventricular dysfunction.

questions.text: A previously healthy 61-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of morning headaches. He also has fatigue and trouble concentrating on his daily tasks at work. He sleeps for 8 hours every night; his wife reports that he sometimes stops breathing for a few seconds while sleeping. His pulse is 71/min and blood pressure is 158/96 mm Hg. He is 178 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 100 kg (220 lb); BMI is 32 kg/m2 . Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's hypertension?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Nocturnal upper airway obstruction resulting from the collapse of the pharyngeal muscles is the pathological mechanism underlying obstructive sleep apnea. Typical features of this disease include snoring, morning headaches, daytime fatigue, and poor concentration. Individuals with OSA often have hypercapnia due to increased retention of carbon dioxide (a consequence of the apneic episodes); this, in turn, causes an increased sympathetic response that leads to secondary hypertension.
Image Description:

Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) is the most common sleep-related breathing disorder and is typically associated with obesity, especially around the neck (short, wide “bull neck”). The relaxation and collapse of the pharyngeal muscles (e.g., tongue, uvula, soft palate) during sleep results in the obstruction of the upper airways. This obstruction causes multiple episodes of interrupted breathing (apnea and hypopnea events) as well as irregular snoring (due to soft-tissue vibrations caused by the obstructed airflow during respiration), gasping, or choking episodes.

B) INCORRECT:

Neoplasms of the hypophysis, such as pituitary adenomas, can cause mass effect leading to headaches and visual disturbances. Increased secretion of ACTH (Cushing disease), growth hormone (acromegaly), or TSH (central hyperthyroidism) could also cause increased blood pressure. However, pituitary adenomas usually cause visual field defects, such as bitemporal hemianopsia, and it would not explain this patient's nocturnal breathing problems.

C) INCORRECT:

Hypersecretion of aldosterone, seen in primary hyperaldosteronism, can present with hypertension and headaches. High systemic aldosterone levels result in increased sodium reabsorption and potassium secretion in the kidney. This, in turn, leads to the retention of water along with sodium, causing hypertension and hypokalemia. However, this patient lacks other common findings of hypokalemia, like muscle weakness, cramping, and polyuria/polydipsia, making this diagnosis less likely. Primary hyperaldosteronism would also not account for his nocturnal breathing problems.

D) INCORRECT:

Cushing syndrome, due to endogenous overproduction of cortisol by the adrenal gland, could explain this patient's hypertension, obesity, and poor concentration. However, patients with Cushing syndrome typically have moon facies, buffalo hump, and abdominal striae, all of which are side effects of systemic glucocorticoid excess and are absent in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

A proliferation of the adrenal chromaffin cells (e.g., pheochromocytoma) could explain this patient's persistent headaches and hypertension. This tumor can present with sustained hypertension, but the headaches are often paroxysmal and accompanied by significant sweating, tachycardia, and pallor, making this diagnosis less likely. It also would not account for his nocturnal breathing problems.

F) INCORRECT:

Low circulating free thyroxine levels, seen in hypothyroidism, could explain this patient's impaired cognition, hypertension, and obesity. However, this patient lacks the more salient features of hypothyroidism, such as cold intolerance, constipation, and skin changes (cold, dry skin and hair loss), making this diagnosis unlikely. It also would not explain his nocturnal breathing problems.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman with hypertension comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of persistent reddening of her face, daytime fatigue, and difficulty concentrating. She has fallen asleep multiple times during important meetings. Her only medication is lisinopril. She is 170 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 88 kg (194 lb); BMI is 30 kg/m2. Her blood pressure is 145/85 mm Hg. Physical examination shows erythema of the face that is especially pronounced around the cheeks, nose, and ears. Fasting serum glucose concentration is 96 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's facial discoloration?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Antibody-mediated vasculopathy is a feature of dermatomyositis. Typical cutaneous manifestations of dermatomyositis include Gottron papules, photosensitive skin lesions (e.g., erythema of the neck), and a heliotrope rash. While dermatomyositis can also present with midfacial erythema, the diagnosis is unlikely in the absence of further typical findings (e.g., muscle weakness, myalgia).
Image Description:

Erythematous papules are visible on the dorsal aspect of the interphalangeal and metacarpophalangeal joints. This is the typical localization of Gottron papules, which are pathognomonic of dermatomyositis.

Periungual erythema is also visible.

B) INCORRECT:

Increased serum cortisol levels are a diagnostic finding in individuals with Cushing syndrome, which can cause hypertension, obesity, fatigue, and facial plethora. However, other typical features of Cushing (e.g., fragile skin, muscle atrophy, abdominal striae, buffalo hump, hyperglycemia) are not present.
Image Description:

Multiple vertical, approx. 2-cm wide, violaceous striae are visible along the lateral and ventral thorax of this 32-year-old, overweight man.

This constellation of features suggests Cushing syndrome.

C) INCORRECT:

A delayed-type hypersensitivity reaction can be the cause of several conditions, such as allergic contact dermatitis or polymorphous light eruption (PLE). PLE should be considered in individuals with an outbreak of pruritic skin lesions following exposure to intense sunlight (especially in spring or summer). While PLE can manifest as facial erythema, the diagnosis is unlikely in a patient without a history of recent travel or outdoor activities and further skin lesions on sun-exposed body parts (e.g., neck, forearms).
Image Description:

Erythematous papules and lesions with irregular borders are visible on the cheeks and forehead.

D) INCORRECT:

Increased bradykinin production is the cause of angioedema, which can be caused by ACE inhibitors (e.g., lisinopril) and occasionally result in facial erythema. However, swelling of the face would be evident and fatigue would not be expected with ACE inhibitor-induced angioedema.
Image Description:

Facial edema, primarily affecting the eyelids, is visible on the patient's face.

E) CORRECT:

In obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), nighttime obstruction of the upper airways (e.g., resulting from obesity) leads to apneic episodes, hypoxia, and poor quality of sleep. Sleep deprivation causes daytime sleepiness and impaired concentration, while hypoxia triggers renal erythropoietin secretion and increased production of RBCs in the bone marrow, resulting in a characteristic red discoloration of the face (plethora). Chronic hypoxia can also trigger a sympathetic response, which could explain this patient's hypertension.

F) INCORRECT:

Increased serum serotonin levels in individuals who are not taking serotonergic medications (e.g., SSRIs) are indicative of carcinoid syndrome. The condition is caused by neuroendocrine tumors that cause diarrhea, abdominal cramps, asthma-like attacks, and facial flushing. While flushing caused by carcinoid syndrome lasts about 30 minutes, this patient has permanent facial discoloration and no gastrointestinal or respiratory symptoms, which makes the diagnosis unlikely.
questions.hint: This overweight patient has increased daytime sleepiness and impaired concentration, making obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) a likely diagnosis.

questions.text: A 57-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of excessive daytime fatigue and difficulty concentrating at work. She also mentions that she is having frequent headaches in the morning. Her partner reports that the patient snores loudly every night. She has hypertension treated with amlodipine and lisinopril; the dose of amlodipine was increased at her last visit 2 months ago. She does not smoke and drinks one glass of wine in the evenings. She is 175 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 108 kg (238 lb); BMI is 37 kg/m2. Her pulse is 74/min, and her blood pressure is 141/88 mm Hg. Neck circumference is 44 cm. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Results of polysomnography confirm the diagnosis. In addition to recommending weight loss and adequate sleep hygiene, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in treatment?

choices.text: No additional treatment is indicated at this time
Nocturnal use of a mandibular advancement device

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Uvulopalatopharyngoplasty (UPPP) is the surgical dilation of the upper airway via resection of the uvula and redundant retrolingual, soft palate, and tonsillar tissue. Although UPPP can be used as adjunctive therapy, another step is more appropriate as first-line treatment for OSA.

B) CORRECT:

Positive airway pressure (PAP) therapy is first-line treatment for all patients with OSA. PAP functions as a pneumatic splint, preventing airway collapse, thereby reducing the frequency of respiratory events. PAP therapy is administered via a mask that can apply continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP), bilateral positive airway pressure (BPAP) with different levels for inhalation and exhalation, or a range of automatic positive airway pressure (APAP) levels. This treatment reduces disease severity, helps to control hypertension, and improves sleep-related quality of life. Alternative treatment methods (e.g., oral appliances, positional therapy) should be considered in patients unable to tolerate PAP.
Image Description:

Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) is the most common sleep-related breathing disorder and is typically associated with obesity, especially around the neck (short, wide “bull neck”). The relaxation and collapse of the pharyngeal muscles (e.g., tongue, uvula, soft palate) during sleep results in the obstruction of the upper airways. This obstruction causes multiple episodes of interrupted breathing (apnea and hypopnea events) as well as irregular snoring (due to soft-tissue vibrations caused by the obstructed airflow during respiration), gasping, or choking episodes.

C) INCORRECT:

Although lifestyle modifications (e.g., adequate sleep hygiene and weight loss) are important components of supportive care, another step is more appropriate as first-line treatment for OSA.

D) INCORRECT:

Hypoglossal nerve stimulation therapy involves the implantation of a pacing device that modulates the genioglossus muscle to reduce airway collapsibility. Although hypoglossal nerve stimulation can be used as an alternative therapy, another step is more appropriate as first-line treatment for OSA.

E) INCORRECT:

Mandibular advancement devices can be used in patients with OSA to move the lower jaw forward, preventing airway collapse. Another step is more appropriate as first-line treatment for OSA.
questions.hint: Daytime fatigue, morning headaches, snoring, hypertension, and an increased neck circumference indicate obstructive sleep apnea (OSA). Polysomnography is used to confirm the diagnosis of OSA and determine its severity.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man with a history of morbid obesity (BMI, 50), untreated obstructive sleep apnea, and type 2 diabetes is admitted with lower-extremity edema and 3 months of progressive dyspnea on exertion. He has never smoked.
A transthoracic echocardiogram performed earlier in the day revealed moderate pulmonary hypertension (right ventricular systolic pressure, 55 mm Hg) with preserved right and left ventricular function, wall motion, and relaxation; the echocardiogram was otherwise normal. The hematocrit was 56% (reference range, 41–53). A chest radiograph showed normal lung parenchyma and low lung volumes due to body habitus.
On examination, the patient’s vital signs are normal, except for an oxygen saturation of 85% while he is breathing ambient air. He has elevated jugular venous pressure, as well as a loud P2 component of the second heart sound on cardiac auscultation. His lungs are clear. He has no rash or synovitis.
An electrocardiogram is obtained (figure).
Which one of the following tests is the most appropriate initial step for identifying the suspected cause of this patient’s hypoxemia, pulmonary hypertension, and peripheral edema?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

If initial studies were unrevealing and the more likely diagnosis of OHS was not confirmed, additional studies such as a pulmonary ventilation-perfusion scan to assess for chronic thromboembolic disease or echocardiography with bubble study to rule out intracardiac or intrapulmonary shunt would be appropriate steps in evaluating a new diagnosis of pulmonary hypertension.

B) CORRECT:

This clinical picture of morbid obesity with known obstructive sleep apnea, pulmonary hypertension with resulting electrocardiographic changes of right-heart strain with right axis deviation and right ventricular hypertrophy, clear lung examination, and resting hypoxemia strongly suggests obesity hypoventilation syndrome (OHS). The hallmark of this disease is daytime hypoventilation and hypercapnia. Arterial blood gas testing is the best initial test to identify OHS in this patient; elevation of the partial pressure of carbon dioxide (i.e., hypercapnia) in the context of morbid obesity without an elevated alveolar-to-arterial oxygen difference would support the diagnosis.

To confirm the diagnosis, full pulmonary function tests (PFTs) including diffusing capacity of the lungs for carbon monoxide need to be obtained to rule out other causes of hypoventilation (such as parenchymal lung disease, neuromuscular disease, or chest wall deformity). In OHS, mildly reduced total lung capacity is often seen because of obesity and resulting restrictive physiology. Spirometry alone would be insufficient because it primarily reveals obstructive lung disease, which is an unlikely diagnosis in this case given the unremarkable lung examination and the clinical presentation that is more typical of OHS.

Key learning point: The most appropriate initial diagnostic test for identifying the cause of decompensated right-heart failure and resting hypoxemia in a patient with morbid obesity who was recently diagnosed with moderate pulmonary hypertension and untreated obstructive sleep apnea is arterial blood gas testing.

C) INCORRECT:

A high-resolution CT scan should not be done unless PFTs are abnormal. Mild parenchymal disease, which would be evident on CT scan but not PFTs, would not explain pulmonary hypertension.

D) INCORRECT:

To confirm the diagnosis, full pulmonary function tests (PFTs) including diffusing capacity of the lungs for carbon monoxide need to be obtained to rule out other causes of hypoventilation (such as parenchymal lung disease, neuromuscular disease, or chest wall deformity). In OHS, mildly reduced total lung capacity is often seen because of obesity and resulting restrictive physiology. Spirometry alone would be insufficient because it primarily reveals obstructive lung disease, which is an unlikely diagnosis in this case given the unremarkable lung examination and the clinical presentation that is more typical of OHS.

E) INCORRECT:

If initial studies were unrevealing and the more likely diagnosis of OHS was not confirmed, additional studies such as a pulmonary ventilation-perfusion scan to assess for chronic thromboembolic disease or echocardiography with bubble study to rule out intracardiac or intrapulmonary shunt would be appropriate steps in evaluating a new diagnosis of pulmonary hypertension.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old man with a BMI of 45 reports chronic fatigue, intermittent morning headaches, and frequent loud snoring. He has a history of type 2 diabetes, advanced chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, hypertension, myocardial infarction, and heart failure with reduced ejection fraction.
Which one of the following evaluations is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary function testing can be used to assess the severity of a patient’s lung disease and help in optimizing medical management. However, it does not aid in diagnosing sleep-disordered breathing.

B) CORRECT:

Patients who have a high risk for obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) and no significant comorbidities can be assessed with either in-laboratory polysomnography or home sleep apnea testing. However, patients with significant underlying cardiopulmonary disease or possible obesity-hypoventilation syndrome should be assessed only with in-laboratory study. Such is the case in this patient, who has severe chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, heart failure with reduced ejection fraction, and a BMI of 45. Patients with cardiopulmonary comorbidities have a much higher risk of other forms of sleep-disordered breathing (e.g., Cheyne-Stokes respiration, sleep-related hypoventilation) that cannot be diagnosed with home sleep apnea testing.

Key learning point: The most appropriate first step in evaluation for a patient with suspected obstructive sleep apnea, morbid obesity, and cardiopulmonary comorbidities is screening with in-laboratory polysomnography.

C) INCORRECT:

Patients who have a high risk for obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) and no significant comorbidities can be assessed with either in-laboratory polysomnography or home sleep apnea testing. However, patients with significant underlying cardiopulmonary disease or possible obesity-hypoventilation syndrome should be assessed only with in-laboratory study. Such is the case in this patient, who has severe chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, heart failure with reduced ejection fraction, and a BMI of 45. Patients with cardiopulmonary comorbidities have a much higher risk of other forms of sleep-disordered breathing (e.g., Cheyne-Stokes respiration, sleep-related hypoventilation) that cannot be diagnosed with home sleep apnea testing.

D) INCORRECT:

Nocturnal oximetry testing can be used to evaluate for nocturnal hypoxemia, which may be caused by any of several disease processes (e.g., chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, sleep-disordered breathing), but such testing is inadequate to diagnose sleep apnea or hypoventilation. A positive nocturnal oximetry test with a characteristic sawtooth pattern should further raise suspicion for OSA, but it is insufficient to confirm a diagnosis of OSA and does not rule out central sleep apnea or additional hypoventilation.

E) INCORRECT:

The Multiple Sleep Latency Test can be used to further evaluate for coexistent narcolepsy or other central hypersomnia. This test would be appropriate only if symptoms of excessive daytime sleepiness persist despite appropriate assessment and treatment of suspected OSA.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old woman reports persistent fatigue. She recently fell asleep briefly while driving home from work but has never been involved in a motor vehicle crash. She lives alone and is not sure whether she snores or has interrupted breathing during sleep. She does report headaches that are usually worse in the morning.
Her blood pressure is 145/82 mm Hg, and her heart rate is 80 beats per minute. Her weight is 82 kg, and her BMI is 32. She has an increased neck circumference of 40 cm but otherwise normal findings on the upper airway examination and general physical examination. Laboratory results (complete blood count, chemistry panel, and thyroid function testing) are normal.
In addition to counseling regarding the importance of healthy sleep habits, which one of the following approaches is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Continuous positive airway pressure therapy (CPAP) therapy is an effective therapeutic option for OSA, but it is not generally initiated until the diagnosis of OSA has been confirmed.

B) INCORRECT:

Modafinil and armodafinil are medications that enhance alertness and that can be used as adjunctive therapies for OSA with hypersomnia, as well as for idiopathic hypersomnia, narcolepsy, and shift-work sleep disorder. These medications are generally prescribed when patients with confirmed OSA have residual sleepiness despite adequate treatment with first-line therapy. Testing for sleep apnea should be performed before treatment with these medications. These drugs may be appropriate if overnight polysomnography does not demonstrate OSA or other sleep disorders and the patient remains excessively sleepy despite adequate sleep.

C) CORRECT:

This patient has hypersomnolence and fatigue, which are common symptoms of obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) and insufficient sleep. Adequate sleep opportunity and optimal sleep timing should be assessed. In addition, a sleep study should be conducted to evaluate for OSA, given the patient's risk factors (BMI >30, high blood pressure, and large neck circumference). This study is typically performed at home (a home sleep-apnea study), although in-laboratory polysomnography is indicated in patients with suspected sleep-disordered breathing other than sleep apnea and in patients with significant cardiopulmonary disease.

Patients with OSA are several times more likely than nonapneic patients to have motor vehicle crashes. Clinicians who are evaluating patients with possible OSA should counsel them about ways to minimize that risk, including restriction of driving until the OSA is treated and sleep is adequate. In addition, diet and exercise should be recommended for this patient, as weight loss can reduce the severity of apnea in patients with OSA.

Key learning point: Hypersomnolence and fatigue are typical symptoms of obstructive sleep apnea; diagnosis with a sleep study and subsequent treatment can help prevent death from motor vehicle crashes attributable to drowsy driving.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient has hypersomnolence and fatigue, which are common symptoms of obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) and insufficient sleep. Overnight pulse oximetry alone is not appropriate as a screening test for OSA.

E) INCORRECT:

Modafinil and armodafinil are medications that enhance alertness and that can be used as adjunctive therapies for OSA with hypersomnia, as well as for idiopathic hypersomnia, narcolepsy, and shift-work sleep disorder. These medications are generally prescribed when patients with confirmed OSA have residual sleepiness despite adequate treatment with first-line therapy. Testing for sleep apnea should be performed before treatment with these medications. These drugs may be appropriate if overnight polysomnography does not demonstrate OSA or other sleep disorders and the patient remains excessively sleepy despite adequate sleep.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes and hypertension presents with fatigue and daytime sleepiness. She weighs 85 kg and has a BMI of 37. Her sleep experience includes frequent loud snoring, gasping, and witnessed apneas.
A home sleep apnea test reveals an apnea-hypopnea index of 24 events per hour (normal, < 5) with a nadir oxygen saturation of 77%. The patient is started on autotitrating continuous positive airway pressure (APAP) therapy set at 5 to 15 cm of water. Weight loss through dietary modification and increased exercise is also recommended.
At a follow-up visit, the patient reports adherence to APAP therapy and improved energy. She has also lost 26 kg because of the lifestyle modifications. Her BMI is now 26. She asks if she has to continue the APAP therapy, as she does not think she snores anymore and would prefer to discontinue it if appropriate. She did not bring her APAP machine with her on a recent monthlong vacation and did not feel any daytime sleepiness as she had in the past.
The data downloaded from her APAP machine show that her mean positive pressure is 6.0 cm of water, with a 90th percentile pressure (the pressure at or below which 90% of obstructive events are eliminated) of 9.2 cm of water. Her residual apnea-hypopnea index is 2.3.
Which one of the following management strategies is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Reduce the maximal APAP pressure to 6 cm of water, and reevaluate response in 4 weeks
Continue APAP therapy at current settings
Schedule a repeat home sleep apnea test
Replace APAP with an oral appliance
Discontinue APAP therapy, and evaluate symptoms in 4 weeks

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Reducing this patient’s maximal pressure to her mean pressure (6 cm of water) is not likely to treat her OSA completely, as pressure would need to be titrated up to at least 9.2 cm of water in order to eliminate 90% of her obstructive events.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient’s request for a reevaluation of her need for CPAP is reasonable, given her weight loss, her desire to discontinue CPAP use if possible, and the fact that she did not experience a relapse of daytime sleepiness off therapy. Simply continuing the current CPAP settings would not address her request and would not be appropriate.

C) CORRECT:

All patients with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) and a BMI ≥ 25 should be counseled about the benefits of weight loss. Successful weight loss through either lifestyle modifications or surgery may improve the apnea-hypopnea index (AHI), and a loss of ≥ 10% of baseline body weight may lead to changes in upper-airway mechanics and reduced obstruction. In some cases, if the OSA is much milder after weight loss and there are no longer significant symptoms, a patient’s continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) therapy may be reasonably stopped, especially if that is the patient’s preference.

This patient’s request for a reevaluation of her need for CPAP is reasonable, given her weight loss, her desire to discontinue CPAP use if possible, and the fact that she did not experience a relapse of daytime sleepiness off therapy. However, her autotitrating continuous positive airway pressure (APAP) device is still titrating up the pressure, which suggests that she still has some degree of OSA. In addition, her OSA was moderate at diagnosis, making it less likely to resolve completely with weight loss. Discontinuing her APAP therapy without verifying significant improvement in her AHI would therefore not be appropriate. A follow-up home sleep study should be conducted to determine whether she still has significant sleep apnea. If only mild OSA is present on the repeat sleep study, she will likely be able to stop CPAP use.

Key learning point: A patient with obstructive sleep apnea who has improved with continuous positive airway pressure therapy and has lost a clinically significant amount of weight because of lifestyle modifications should undergo follow-up that includes a repeat home sleep apnea test.

D) INCORRECT:

Switching to another therapy (e.g., an oral appliance) is not indicated and would likely be costly.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient’s request for a reevaluation of her need for CPAP is reasonable, given her weight loss, her desire to discontinue CPAP use if possible, and the fact that she did not experience a relapse of daytime sleepiness off therapy. However, her autotitrating continuous positive airway pressure (APAP) device is still titrating up the pressure, which suggests that she still has some degree of OSA. In addition, her OSA was moderate at diagnosis, making it less likely to resolve completely with weight loss. Discontinuing her APAP therapy without verifying significant improvement in her AHI would therefore not be appropriate.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old man reports fatigue, as well as difficulty falling and staying asleep for the past year. He goes to bed at 10 p.m. every night, does not fall asleep until midnight, and awakens four to five times per night, usually to find that his bedding is disheveled. Upon waking up at 5 a.m., he feels unrefreshed.
The patient’s other reported symptoms include frequent snoring, worsening concentration and memory, and frequent depressed mood. He reports no witnessed apneas, morning headaches, nocturnal paresthesias, or significant psychosocial stressors. His medical history is unremarkable.
On physical examination, his BMI is 31, and his neck circumference is 43 cm.
Which one of the following evaluations is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: A 2-week sleep diary completed by the patient
Referral to an otolaryngologist for consideration of flexible laryngoscopy

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Testing serum ferritin levels would be appropriate if the patient had excessive periodic limb movements during polysomnography and symptoms consistent with restless legs syndrome, as this condition is associated with iron storage deficiency.

B) INCORRECT:

A sleep diary should be completed after a full-night polysomnogram rules out other suspected sleep disorders. Sleep diaries may be helpful in the assessment of insomnia and circadian rhythm disorders.

C) INCORRECT:

Flexible laryngoscopy is an effective way to visualize the upper airway, but it is not considered an initial evaluation for suspected sleep disorders. It may be considered after a sleep disorder has been diagnosed if the disorder is felt to be related to structural abnormalities of the airway.

D) INCORRECT:

A Multiple Sleep Latency Test would be indicated for an evaluation of narcolepsy or idiopathic hypersomnia but would not be performed before a full-night polysomnogram.

E) CORRECT:

This patient likely has insomnia and possibly other sleep disorders comorbid with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA). Patients with possible comorbid sleep disorders should undergo in-laboratory polysomnography, which allows for evaluation for sleep disorders other than OSA, such as periodic limb-movement disorder, parasomnias, and rapid-eye-movement sleep-behavior disorder. In this case, there are many features, such as delayed sleep onset and the disheveled bed, that raise concern for sleep disorders other than OSA. Therefore, in-laboratory polysomnography is the best test. In clinical practice, a home sleep apnea test may be required initially for insurance purposes, but it should then be followed by in-laboratory polysomnography to assess for sleep disorders other than sleep apnea.

Key learning point: A patient with insomnia that is associated with frequent snoring, a disheveled bed, worsening concentration and memory, and frequent depressed mood should be evaluated with in-laboratory full-night polysomnography.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old man presents for evaluation of hypertension that was diagnosed 15 years ago. His blood pressure has been difficult to control despite his adherence to treatment with furosemide 40 mg, amlodipine 10 mg, lisinopril 40 mg, and atenolol 100 mg, all taken daily. He reports no other medical diagnoses and takes no other medications.
His current blood pressure is 162/89 mm Hg, and his BMI is 32.
Which one of the following findings would most likely be present on physical examination as a potential explanation for this patient’s drug-resistant hypertension?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Coarctation of the aorta (causing a radiofemoral pulse delay), Cushing syndrome (causing supraclavicular fat pads), and polycystic kidney disease (causing palpable kidneys) are seen in less than 1% of patients with drug-resistant hypertension

B) CORRECT:

A patient with drug-resistant hypertension (defined as uncontrolled blood pressure despite use of three or more antihypertensive medications, including one diuretic, at optimal doses) should be assessed for secondary causes of hypertension. The most common secondary causes of hypertension are primary hyperaldosteronism, renal-artery stenosis, chronic kidney disease, and obstructive sleep apnea.

Found in up to 83% of patients with difficult-to-control (resistant) hypertension, obstructive sleep apnea is one of the most common conditions associated with drug-resistant hypertension. A large neck circumference (>40 cm in women, >43 cm in men) suggests a greater likelihood of obstructive sleep apnea, as do male sex, general obesity, loud snoring, and daytime sleepiness. A crowded oral airway on examination would also support obstructive sleep apnea.

Key learning point: A patient with drug-resistant hypertension and a large neck size (>40 cm in women, >43 cm in men) should be screened for obstructive sleep apnea.

C) INCORRECT:

Coarctation of the aorta (causing a radiofemoral pulse delay), Cushing syndrome (causing supraclavicular fat pads), and polycystic kidney disease (causing palpable kidneys) are seen in less than 1% of patients with drug-resistant hypertension.

D) INCORRECT:

Coarctation of the aorta (causing a radiofemoral pulse delay), Cushing syndrome (causing supraclavicular fat pads), and polycystic kidney disease (causing palpable kidneys) are seen in less than 1% of patients with drug-resistant hypertension.

E) INCORRECT:

An abdominal bruit can be detected occasionally in patients with renal-artery stenosis; however, renal-artery stenosis is present in only 3% to 4% of patients with drug-resistant hypertension.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old man reports fatigue and diminished libido. Starting a year ago, but not before then, his interest in sex waned; he now rarely awakes with an erection, and he achieves only a modest erection when masturbating. Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) should be considered in this patient with obesity, hypogonadism, and daytime fatigue. OSA frequently coexists with obesity and has been associated with hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. Sleep deprivation results in lowered testosterone levels, as does sleep restriction in the first half of the rest period. Obesity causes both OSA and hypogonadotropic hypogonadism.

OSA is best diagnosed with a sleep study. Testosterone levels and OSA typically improve after appropriate weight loss treatment, but testosterone levels do not reliably improve by solely applying continuous positive airway pressure for OSA. Ruling out OSA is especially relevant when the use of testosterone is being considered, because untreated severe OSA is a contraindication to the use of testosterone replacement.

Key learning point: Morning headaches and daytime fatigue in a man with obesity and a low testosterone level are most likely to be attributable to obstructive sleep apnea.

B) INCORRECT:

Although hypogonadotropic hypogonadism can be due to a congenital disorder such as idiopathic hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, Kallmann syndrome, or Prader-Willi syndrome, patients with those conditions usually present with symptoms at an early age and do not have a normal puberty experience or a normal reproductive history. Therefore, karyotype testing is not indicated in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Men with a pituitary cause of hypogonadism often have extremely low testosterone levels; pituitary tumors and elevated prolactin levels must be ruled out in adults with recent-onset secondary hypogonadism if the testosterone level is very low. Given that this patient is more likely to have obstructive sleep apnea than a pituitary problem, a sleep study is more appropriate than a pituitary MRI.

A testicular ultrasound is unlikely to be helpful in evaluating a patient with low gonadotropin levels.

Although chronic opioid use is a common cause of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, evaluation for opioid use is unlikely to be diagnostic in the absence of suggestive features, such as surreptitious drug-seeking behavior, particularly in a patient whose symptoms of fatigue and morning headache are consistent with obstructive sleep apnea.

questions.solution:

Testosterone supplementation is not appropriate for people with untreated obstructive sleep apnea (OSA). According to clinical guidelines from the Endocrine Society, OSA is a relative contraindication for starting testosterone therapy. Testosterone therapy can increase neck size and alter ventilator response and airway mechanics, all of which can worsen sleep apnea. Exogenous testosterone can increase the apnea-hypopnea index and desaturation severity.

B) INCORRECT:

Clomiphene is a selective estrogen-receptor modulator that increases gonadotropin levels. It is of questionable clinical benefit for managing low testosterone levels. In addition, reversible etiologies of hypogonadism should be thoroughly evaluated before such treatment options are considered.

C) INCORRECT:

The insulin-like growth factor 1 level would be checked if acromegaly were suspected. Although acromegaly can cause increased snoring, patients with acromegaly have coarse facial features and increasing shoe and ring sizes.

D) CORRECT:

This patient's increased fatigue and tendency to fall asleep in the afternoon, along with his obesity and large neck circumference, all suggest a diagnosis of obstructive sleep apnea (OSA). The diagnosis of OSA should be confirmed by a sleep study.

The patient’s decline in libido and small testes are consistent with low testosterone levels. Both obesity and OSA are common secondary causes of low testosterone levels in men.
