E) INCORRECT:

A testicular ultrasound is not necessary in a patient with low gonadotropin levels.

questions.text:
A 73-year-old woman reports headaches that occur almost daily when she wakes in the morning. The headaches — which are bilateral and throbbing but not associated with photophobia or phonophobia — last an average of 30 minutes. The patient also has difficulty remaining asleep and reports daytime fatigue and irritability. The only triggers she can identify are stress, alcohol use, and sleep deprivation. Her medical history is significant only for hypertension.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tension-type headaches can be made worse with stress but are not typically worse in the mornings or associated with daytime fatigue.

B) CORRECT:

Sleep apnea headaches can occur independently of, or exacerbate, tension-type and migraine headaches. Sleep apnea headaches are typically bifrontal and dull in nature and should resolve shortly after awakening, although they can last as long as 4 hours. The signs and symptoms of sleep apnea include snoring, daytime fatigue and irritability, and hypertension. Obesity and a large neck circumference (>43 cm in men, >40 cm in women) each increase the risk for sleep apnea.

Patients with suspected sleep apnea headaches should undergo a sleep study to confirm the diagnosis and begin treatment. Treatment will help both the sleep apnea and the resulting headaches.

Key learning point: The combination of chronic morning headaches, poor sleep quality, and daytime sleepiness and fatigue is most suggestive of a diagnosis of sleep apnea headache.

C) INCORRECT:

Cluster headaches are severe, short, unilateral headaches and are associated with autonomic symptoms such as lacrimation and rhinorrhea.

D) INCORRECT:

Elevated intracranial pressure from a tumor such as a meningioma can cause morning headaches; thus, neuroimaging is likely required in this case. However, hypertension and daytime fatigue are more typical of sleep apnea headaches.

E) INCORRECT:

Migraine headaches often resolve with sleep rather than occur upon waking, although they can sometimes be present in the morning. Photophobia and phonophobia are commonly associated with migraine but are not specific for migraine.

questions.text:
A 64-year-old woman with hypertension, type 2 diabetes, and obesity (BMI, 54) presents to discuss her newly diagnosed obesity-hypoventilation syndrome (OHS) and obstructive sleep apnea (OSA).
She initially presented one month ago with excessive daytime sleepiness, snoring, and witnessed nocturnal apneas. Her serum bicarbonate level at the time was elevated, and her partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO2) on daytime arterial blood gas measurement was 53 mm Hg (reference range, 35–45). An in-laboratory diagnostic polysomnogram revealed moderate OSA with an apnea-hypopnea index of 21 events per hour (normal, <5); the test revealed no central apneas but did show several episodes of desaturation overnight as low as 83% with a mean saturation of 89%. Continuous capnometry showed average end-tidal carbon dioxide levels of 52 mm Hg.
The patient does not use tobacco, consume alcohol, or take any opioids or benzodiazepines.
In addition to aggressive interventions to achieve weight loss, which one of the following therapies is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Modafinil can help promote daytime wakefulness via central nervous system stimulation (by an unclear mechanism). It is approved for use in shift-work-related sleep disorder and narcolepsy, as well as for patients with OSA and OHS who remain sleepy during the day despite demonstrating adherence to appropriate PAP therapy. However, it is not the primary therapy in obesity-hypoventilation syndrome, only an adjuvant to PAP. It will not treat the hypoxemia and hypoventilation, only mask the symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

Acetazolamide acts as a respiratory stimulant but is not first-line therapy for obesity-hypoventilation syndrome. It can be used as an alternative therapy in patients who continue to have hypoventilation despite nocturnal positive pressure therapy, but this must be done with caution. Acetazolamide use can result in excessive loss of bicarbonate, effectively removing the patient’s compensatory metabolic alkalosis, and can excessively increase the patient’s work of breathing.

C) INCORRECT:

Methylphenidate is used to treat attention-deficit disorder and narcolepsy. It can be helpful for managing symptoms of daytime drowsiness in a variety of patients. However, it should not be used as monotherapy for obesity-hypoventilation syndrome. It does not address the underlying ventilation issue, which can lead to pulmonary hypertension, sudden cardiac death, and other long-term consequences.

D) INCORRECT:

Oxygen alone may help the overnight hypoxemia, but it does not address hypoventilation or hypercapnia. More than 90% of patients with obesity-hypoventilation syndrome also have OSA, and oxygen will not treat the OSA.

E) CORRECT:

In patients with obesity-hypoventilation syndrome and concurrent obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), positive airway pressure (PAP) is first-line therapy. An in-laboratory PAP titration sleep study is used to determine whether continuous PAP or bilevel PAP is necessary. Continuous PAP should be trialed first, during the in-laboratory study; bilevel PAP is only required if hypoventilation persists despite treatment of the obstruction with CPAP. Lifestyle interventions to achieve weight loss should be recommended for all patients with obesity-hypoventilation syndrome. Weight-loss medications and bariatric surgery may also be considered.

Key learning point: In addition to recommending lifestyle changes to achieve weight loss, the most appropriate therapy for a patient with obesity-hypoventilation syndrome is either continuous or bilevel positive airway pressure therapy.

questions.text:
A 54-year-old man with morbid obesity (BMI, 46) and hypertension presents for follow-up to discuss ongoing excessive sleepiness and dyspnea with exertion. He reports that he has fallen asleep at his desk at work and sitting in his car in traffic, despite drinking several cups of coffee during the day. He experiences dyspnea after climbing two flights of stairs at work but has had this for several years. He does not routinely exercise but is able to do heavy yard work at home without associated chest pain or wheezing. He has no orthopnea or changes in his chronic lower-extremity edema.
His only current medication is lisinopril. He does not smoke cigarettes, drink alcohol, or take any sedating medications.
On physical examination, the patient has a heart rate of 90 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 142/82 mm Hg, an oxygen saturation of 93% while breathing ambient air, a large neck without goiter, and a crowded posterior oropharynx with only the base of the uvula visible. There is no visible jugular venous distention. Both lungs are clear, and the heart rate and rhythm are regular without audible murmurs. The abdomen is obese. Both lower extremities exhibit mild edema with chronic stasis changes. The patient has full strength in all extremities.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hypothyroidism is a potential cause of chronic fatigue. Given the patient’s normal thyroid-stimulating hormone level and unremarkable thyroid examination, symptomatic hypothyroidism is unlikely, and checking a free thyroxine level is not necessary.

B) INCORRECT:

If the patient complained of exertional chest pain or progressive exertional shortness of breath, a cardiac stress test would be indicated to evaluate for coronary artery disease. In the absence of such symptoms, this test would not aid in the evaluation of the patient’s hypersomnia.

C) CORRECT:

This patient’s elevated apnea-hypopnea index is indicative of moderate obstructive sleep apnea (OSA). Patients with OSA who have severe sleepiness and elevated serum bicarbonate levels on laboratory testing should be evaluated for concomitant obesity-hypoventilation syndrome (OHS) with daytime arterial blood gas measurement, as 90% of patients with OHS also have OSA.

Patients with OHS present with daytime hypersomnia in the setting of obesity, as well as hypercapnia (partial pressure of carbon dioxide [PaCO2 ] >45 mm Hg), which is necessary for diagnosis. As a result, serum bicarbonate levels are usually elevated as well (>30 mEq/liter); in this patient, the serum bicarbonate level of 34 mEq/liter is an additional clue to the diagnosis but is not definitively diagnostic. Treatment of OHS involves weight loss, avoidance of sedating medications, and primarily nocturnal noninvasive positive pressure therapy. Sometimes, patients with OSA and OHS can be managed successfully with CPAP therapy alone, but if daytime or nocturnal hypercapnia persists, switching to bilevel positive airway pressure is indicated.

Full pulmonary function testing with lung volumes and diffusing capacity for carbon monoxide may be indicated once hypoventilation is confirmed, to rule out other possible diagnoses. In OHS, lung volumes may be reduced, but the remainder of the pulmonary function tests should be normal. This helps exclude asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (which are unlikely in this patient with stable symptoms and no wheezes on lung examination to suggest obstruction) as well as interstitial lung disease.

Key learning point: The most appropriate initial evaluation for a patient with obesity and obstructive sleep apnea who has severe hypersomnia and an elevated serum bicarbonate level is arterial blood gas testing to evaluate for concomitant obesity-hypoventilation syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

Ambulatory oximetry is helpful in the evaluation for intrinsic cardiac or lung disease, but it is not used in the diagnosis of OHS, because patients with OHS and no underlying pulmonary hypertension would not be expected to desaturate on oximetry with walking.

E) INCORRECT:

Depression and associated sleep derangements can contribute to daytime fatigue and sleepiness, but it is important to first exclude other medical causes of hypersomnia, such as OHS, in addition to the patient’s known OSA.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old man with a history of hypertension and morbid obesity (BMI, 40.9) presents for follow-up after a recent hospitalization for a small lacunar infarction. He reports adherence to his discharge medications: clopidogrel, atorvastatin, amlodipine, chlorthalidone, and losartan. His current blood pressure is 142/95 mm Hg, and his heart rate is 72 beats per minute (bpm). The rest of his physical examination is normal. He is asymptomatic and has returned to his functional baseline.
At discharge, he had an event monitor placed to look for intermittent atrial fibrillation. The results are available in the clinic today:

Average heart rate: 78 bpm
Maximum heart rate: 124 bpm (8:25 AM)
Minimum heart rate: 34 bpm (3:17 AM)
Maximum RR interval: 3.4 seconds (4:46 AM)
Percent atrial fibrillation: 0.0%
No symptoms reported

Review of the waveforms reveals several events during the early morning hours, similar to the example in the figure.
What is the most appropriate next step in evaluation for this patient?

choices.text: Perform serologic tests for Lyme disease
Refer for pacemaker implantation without additional testing
Continue current management without additional testing
Refer for polysomnography to assess for underlying obstructive sleep apnea
Discontinue amlodipine and repeat the event monitor

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although Lyme disease is an important and potentially remediable cause of bradycardia, OSA is a more likely cause in this patient who has refractory hypertension, a lacunar stroke, and morbid obesity. The nighttime predilection in this case provides further evidence that OSA is more likely than Lyme disease.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient does not meet criteria for pacemaker therapy until all the other causes noted above are excluded. Continuing current management without further testing would be inappropriate as the patient has a documented severe arrhythmia with a potentially treatable underlying cause.

C) INCORRECT:

Continuing current management without further testing would be inappropriate as the patient has a documented severe arrhythmia with a potentially treatable underlying cause.

D) CORRECT:

This patient was found to have nocturnal bradycardia, first-degree atrioventricular nodal block, and blocked atrial beats during monitoring for atrial fibrillation. The finding of an RR interval >3 seconds in sinus rhythm should prompt an evaluation for reversible causes of bradycardia, which can include medications, obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), a vagal response in the setting of pain or urinary retention, and infectious causes. In the absence of secondary causes, the finding would reflect advanced conduction-system disease and would be an indication for referral for pacemaker therapy, even in the absence of symptoms.

The first step in evaluating bradyarrhythmias, including those with conduction abnormalities, is a thorough medication history and discontinuation of any atrioventricular nodal blocking agents (such as beta-blockers and nondihydropyridine calcium-channel blockers). This patient is not taking any of these medications, so the next step is to focus on the patient’s risk factors for other causes of bradycardia. In this case, polysomnography for OSA is warranted given the patient’s age, sex, morbid obesity, and refractory hypertension. If the polysomnogram confirms OSA, the bradycardia should resolve with continuous positive airway pressure, and a pacemaker would not be indicated. If the polysomnogram is normal, other potential causes of reversible bradycardia should be evaluated.

Key learning point: Uncontrolled obstructive sleep apnea is a common reversible cause of nocturnal bradycardia in patients with refractory hypertension.

E) INCORRECT:

Discontinuing the amlodipine and repeating the event monitor is not necessary in this case, as a dihydropyridine calcium-channel blocker is not likely to cause bradycardia.

questions.text:
A 10-year-old girl presents with her father for evaluation of worsening grades in school. He reports that during the past year, and especially the past few months, she has had increasing difficulty completing her schoolwork, paying attention in class, and remembering her assignments. He regularly checks in with her about her homework, and she can complete it with prompting.
He notes that she seems very tired at the end of the day, often taking a nap when she gets home from school, and that her teacher has said she seems sleepy throughout the day. He is concerned that she is not sleeping well and says that she seems restless during sleep. He thinks she may snore but is not sure.
When the patient is interviewed directly, she reports feeling "really tired" during the day and wishing she could take a nap in the afternoons. She also mentions feeling "down" because her grades "aren’t as good as they used to be.” She denies any drug use.
On physical examination, her weight, height, blood pressure, and temperature are normal for her age. She appears well. Examination of her oropharynx reveals mildly enlarged tonsils without petechiae, erythema, or vesicles. Cardiac and respiratory examinations are normal, and there is no cervical lymphadenopathy.
Which one of the following tests is the most appropriate next step in evaluating this patient?

choices.text: School assessment for an individualized education plan
Portable pulse oximetry at home during sleep

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Attention-deficit disorder and depression should also be part of the differential diagnosis for this patient, given the signs of inattention and depressed mood. However, her history of daytime fatigue with possible snoring points to a primary sleep disorder. If her polysomnogram is normal, the next step will be to evaluate her for other causes of inattention and depressed mood.

B) INCORRECT:

Although allergic rhinitis may contribute to nasal obstruction and sleep disorders, it is generally not the primary cause of sleep-disordered breathing in children; thus, referral for allergy evaluation is not appropriate for this patient at this time.

C) INCORRECT:

Attention-deficit disorder and depression should also be part of the differential diagnosis for this patient, given the signs of inattention and depressed mood. However, her history of daytime fatigue with possible snoring points to a primary sleep disorder. If her polysomnogram is normal, the next step will be to evaluate her for other causes of inattention and depressed mood. A school assessment for learning challenges could also be considered at that time but not before the polysomnogram.

D) INCORRECT:

Pulse oximetry at home has limited accuracy in this setting. Most children with sleep-disordered breathing or obstructive sleep disorders do not demonstrate evidence of significant oxygen desaturation during obstructive events. A polysomnography is instead the preferred test.

E) CORRECT:

This patient's history of chronic fatigue, restless sleep, possible snoring, and worsening school performance is concerning for sleep-disordered breathing. The physical finding of mildly enlarged tonsils suggests the possibility of obstructive sleep apnea syndrome (OSAS) secondary to adenotonsillar hypertrophy.

The gold standard for diagnosing OSAS is overnight polysomnography. If this patient is found to have OSAS secondary to adenotonsillar hypertrophy, she will be a candidate for surgical adenotonsillectomy. Children with OSAS treated with adenotonsillectomy have been found to have improvements in school performance, sleep disturbance, emotional distress, and perceived quality of life.

Key learning point: The most appropriate next step in evaluation for a child with tonsillar hypertrophy and suspected sleep-disordered breathing is overnight polysomnography.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old boy with obesity and intermittent asthma presents for an annual well-child visit. He has been attempting to lose weight with the help of your institution’s weight center but reports difficulty. He denies any major new health concerns but notes that he occasionally has a dull headache when he wakes up in the morning. The headaches are not associated with any vision changes, never wake him in the night, and always resolve shortly after he gets out of bed.
His current BMI is 43.5 (>99th percentile; 160% of the 95th percentile). His blood pressure (BP) in the right upper extremity is 137/86 mm Hg, consistent with findings from ambulatory BP monitoring conducted by the weight center last month.
Physical examination reveals acanthosis nigricans at the posterior aspect of the patient’s neck, as well as prominent tonsils.
Recent laboratory results, obtained through the weight center, include a normal complete blood count, a normal comprehensive metabolic panel, and a glycated hemoglobin level of 6.0% (reference range, 4.5–5.6).
A previous renal ultrasound was normal.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Referral to neurology for headache evaluation

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient with class 3 obesity has had multiple elevated blood pressure (BP) measurements consistent with stage 1 hypertension. His screening laboratory evaluation is notable for signs of early metabolic disorder but does not suggest a renal etiology for the hypertension. Instead, his morning headaches, large tonsils, and obesity point to another potential etiology — obstructive sleep apnea (OSA).

OSA affects up to 5% of children and adolescents in the United States and may be associated with significant behavioral and health consequences. Hypertension is seen in a significant subset of adolescents with OSA, particularly those with comorbid obesity, and OSA is important to consider in adolescents with otherwise unexplained or refractory hypertension. A sleep study is an important screening tool when OSA is being considered, particularly because a diagnosis of severe OSA will meaningfully change perioperative management.

In-laboratory polysomnography is the recommended diagnostic test for sleep-disordered breathing in children and adolescents.

Adenotonsillectomy is the gold-standard therapy for managing OSA in children and adolescents and is associated with improvement in diastolic BP load and even resolution of hypertension in some patients.

Key learning point: The combination of obesity, hypertension, and large tonsils in an adolescent should prompt evaluation for obstructive sleep apnea.

B) INCORRECT:

Lisinopril is one of the recommended agents for treating hypertension. However, in this patient with stage 1 hypertension (130/80–139/89 mm Hg in children ≥13 years) who has a normal creatinine level, it is advisable to delay pharmacotherapy until after a modifiable cause of the hypertension is evaluated and potentially treated.

C) INCORRECT:

Home sleep testing may be appropriate for some older adolescents and for adults when OSA is strongly suspected. However, home sleep testing does not include measurement of end-tidal carbon dioxide and, therefore, would be suboptimal for screening this patient, who has morning headaches and is at increased risk for obesity-related hypoventilation.

D) INCORRECT:

A lateral neck radiograph can help identify adenoidal hypertrophy in children but is not sufficient to diagnose OSA or to appropriately risk-stratify patients for whom adenotonsillectomy is a consideration.

E) INCORRECT:

Neurology referral is not yet warranted in this patient, as a sleep-related cause of his morning headaches has not yet been evaluated. If this patient had more-severe, persistent headaches with associated vision changes, pediatric idiopathic intracranial hypertension would be an important consideration.

questions.text:
A 4-year-old girl has been having behavioral problems in her pre-kindergarten class during the past 5 months. The teacher has expressed concern to the mother about attention deficit-hyperactivity disorder, citing the girl’s irritability, inability to finish tasks, tendency to talk during quiet time, and fights with other children. The mother, who is a single parent and has a boyfriend who is not involved in the child’s care, states that she is having difficulty dealing with her daughter on her own. She asks if a stimulant medication would be indicated.
On further review of systems, the girl is growing and developing normally. She sleeps an average of 11 hours a night, occasionally snores, and will often sweat through her sheets. She has had three ear infections requiring antibiotics during the past year. She reports intermittent constipation and early morning headaches.
On physical examination, her heart rate, respiratory rate, and temperature are within normal range for her age. Her blood pressure is in the 99th percentile for age, sex, and height. She has enlarged tonsils, normal nasal turbinates, and normal tympanic membranes. Her lungs are clear to auscultation, without wheezes or crackles. Her heart has a regular rate and rhythm, with normal S1 and S2 heart sounds and no murmurs. Her abdomen is nontender and nondistended, with normal bowel sounds and no hepatomegaly. She has no skin or extremity findings, including rashes.
Which one of the following referrals is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient’s history, constellation of symptoms, and physical findings all suggest obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), a disorder characterized by episodes of partial or complete obstruction of the upper airway during sleep. The presenting symptoms of OSA in children often include behavioral problems, learning difficulties, snoring, sweating at night, and nocturnal enuresis. Daytime sleepiness is not a common presenting symptom in young children like it is in older children and adults. A history of persistent snoring or significant pauses in breathing during sleep can often be elicited from the child’s parents, as in this case.

Polysomnography is the gold-standard test for diagnosis of OSA, and adenotonsillectomy is the first-line treatment in this age group. A referral to otolaryngology would therefore be appropriate for this patient.

Key learning point: A child presenting with nightly snoring and hyperactivity symptoms should be evaluated for obstructive sleep apnea.

B) INCORRECT:

A neurology referral is not indicated for this patient, whose headaches are more likely to be secondary to OSA.

C) INCORRECT:

A nephrology referral would be indicated if the child’s hypertension persisted despite treatment of OSA, but it would not be indicated at this time.

D) INCORRECT:

Child protective services should be contacted in cases of suspected abuse. Although behavioral problems can be a sign of abuse in young children, it is less likely in this case given the patient's constellation of symptoms and the absence of bruises or limb pain.

E) INCORRECT:

Referring this patient to child psychiatry to evaluate for attention deficit-hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) without first investigating for OSA would be inappropriate. Patients with OSA are often misdiagnosed as having ADHD and therefore remain untreated. Untreated OSA is associated with significant morbidity, including neurocognitive impairment, behavioral problems, failure to thrive, hypertension, cardiac dysfunction, and systemic inflammation.

questions.text: A previously healthy 61-year-old man comes to the office because of a 6-month history of morning headaches. He also has fatigue and trouble concentrating on his daily tasks at work. He sleeps for 8 hours every night; his wife reports that he sometimes stops breathing for a few seconds while sleeping. His pulse is 71/min and blood pressure is 158/96 mm Hg. ; BMI is 32 kg/m2 . Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's hypertension?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Nocturnal upper airway obstruction resulting from the collapse of the pharyngeal muscles is the pathological mechanism underlying obstructive sleep apnea. Typical features of this disease include snoring, morning headaches, daytime fatigue, and poor concentration. Individuals with OSA often have hypercapnia due to increased retention of carbon dioxide (a consequence of the apneic episodes); this, in turn, causes an increased sympathetic response that leads to secondary hypertension.
Image Description:

Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) is the most common sleep-related breathing disorder and is typically associated with obesity, especially around the neck (short, wide “bull neck”). The relaxation and collapse of the pharyngeal muscles (e.g., tongue, uvula, soft palate) during sleep results in the obstruction of the upper airways. This obstruction causes multiple episodes of interrupted breathing (apnea and hypopnea events) as well as irregular snoring (due to soft-tissue vibrations caused by the obstructed airflow during respiration), gasping, or choking episodes.

B) INCORRECT:

Neoplasms of the hypophysis, such as pituitary adenomas, can cause mass effect leading to headaches and visual disturbances. Increased secretion of ACTH (Cushing disease), growth hormone (acromegaly), or TSH (central hyperthyroidism) could also cause increased blood pressure. However, pituitary adenomas usually cause visual field defects, such as bitemporal hemianopsia, and it would not explain this patient's nocturnal breathing problems.

C) INCORRECT:

Hypersecretion of aldosterone, seen in primary hyperaldosteronism, can present with hypertension and headaches. High systemic aldosterone levels result in increased sodium reabsorption and potassium secretion in the kidney. This, in turn, leads to the retention of water along with sodium, causing hypertension and hypokalemia. However, this patient lacks other common findings of hypokalemia, like muscle weakness, cramping, and polyuria/polydipsia, making this diagnosis less likely. A 37-year-old woman comes to the office because of a 10-month history of excessive daytime sleepiness and fatigue. She says she has fallen asleep at work on numerous occasions. She has no difficulty falling asleep at night, but wakes up gasping for breath at least once. She has always snored loudly. She has occasional lower back pain, for which she takes tramadol tablets 1–2 times per week. She also began taking one rabeprazole tablet daily 3 weeks ago. She is 175 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 119 kg (262 lb); BMI is 39 kg/m2. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical and neurologic examinations show no other abnormalities. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows:


pH
7.35


PCO2
51 mm Hg


PO2

64 mm Hg


HCO3-

29 mEq/L


O2 saturation
92%


An x-ray of the chest and ECG show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's blood gas abnormalities?

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Central respiratory depression due to deceleration of rhythmic impulses from the respiratory center in the CNS can occur secondary to opioid overdose. The resulting hypoventilation would cause abnormalities in arterial blood gas analysis similar to those seen in this patient, who is taking tramadol. However, tramadol is generally considered safer than most opioids with regard to respiratory depression and this patient's occasional tramadol use is not enough to cause respiratory depression. In this obese patient, another diagnosis is more likely.

B) INCORRECT:

Skeletal abnormalities of the chest wall (e.g., kyphoscoliosis, pectus excavatum) can restrict respiratory excursion, resulting in hypoventilation and arterial blood gas findings similar to those seen in this patient. However, chest wall abnormalities that would be severe enough to cause such symptoms would be obvious on clinical examination and/or on imaging.

C) INCORRECT:

Chronic inflammatory airflow limitation is the mechanism of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). The main findings are chronic cough with expectoration, dyspnea, early inspiratory coarse crackles, and wheezing, as well as a prolonged expiratory phase and decreased breath sounds. Arterial blood gas analysis will show findings similar to what is seen in this patient: decreased pO2 and daytime hypercapnia due to air trapping as a result of expiratory collapse of small airways. However, chest x-ray would likely show signs of hyperinflation (e.g., horizontal ribs and widened intercostal spaces, increased anteroposterior diameter, flattened diaphragm). Furthermore, COPD predominantly affects patients with a history of smoking, making it unlikely in this nonsmoker.

D) INCORRECT:

Thickening of alveolar membranes with impaired gas exchange is characteristic of interstitial lung disease, which manifests with exertional dyspnea that progresses to dyspnea at rest, persistent nonproductive cough, and fatigue. Arterial blood gas analysis will show low partial oxygen pressure and respiratory acidosis due to impaired gas exchange, but only in the late stages of disease. Given the absence of pulmonary symptoms, this patient is unlikely to have advanced interstitial lung disease. Furthermore, chest x-ray in interstitial lung disease is likely to show an increase in reticular opacities, indicating fibrosis, whereas this patient's x-ray findings are normal.

Obesity hypoventilation syndrome (OHS) is characterized by awake alveolar hypoventilation resulting in daytime hypercapnia and respiratory acidosis. Metabolic compensation (elevated HCO3-) is usually also present and indicates that the hypercapnia and respiratory acidosis is chronic. Obesity reduces inspiratory muscle strength and restricts respiratory excursions, resulting in alveolar hypoventilation. Moreover, obesity is associated with increased production of CO2 as a result of the larger body surface area, further contributing to hypercapnia. OHS can be diagnosed in patients with BMI ≥ 30 kg/m2 with symptoms similar to OSA (excessive daytime sleepiness, restless sleep, snoring with apneic episodes) and evidence of daytime alveolar hypoventilation on arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis that cannot be otherwise explained.

90% of patients with OHS also have obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) and distinguishing the two conditions can be challenging because the risk factors and symptoms are very similar. The main difference between the two conditions is that the ABG abnormalities are diurnal in OHS and nocturnal in OSA.

Modafinil can help promote daytime wakefulness via central nervous system stimulation (by an unclear mechanism). It is approved for use in shift-work-related sleep disorder and narcolepsy, as well as for patients with OSA and OHS who remain sleepy during the day despite demonstrating adherence to appropriate PAP therapy. However, it is not the primary therapy in obesity-hypoventilation syndrome, only an adjuvant to PAP. It will not treat the hypoxemia and hypoventilation, only mask the symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

It can be used as an alternative therapy in patients who continue to have hypoventilation despite nocturnal positive pressure therapy, but this must be done with caution. Acetazolamide use can result in excessive loss of bicarbonate, effectively removing the patient’s compensatory metabolic alkalosis, and can excessively increase the patient’s work of breathing.

C) INCORRECT:

Methylphenidate is used to treat attention-deficit disorder and narcolepsy. It can be helpful for managing symptoms of daytime drowsiness in a variety of patients. However, it should not be used as monotherapy for obesity-hypoventilation syndrome. It does not address the underlying ventilation issue, which can lead to pulmonary hypertension, sudden cardiac death, and other long-term consequences.

Oxygen alone may help the overnight hypoxemia, but it does not address hypoventilation or hypercapnia. More than 90% of patients with obesity-hypoventilation syndrome also have OSA, and oxygen will not treat the OSA.

An in-laboratory PAP titration sleep study is used to determine whether continuous PAP or bilevel PAP is necessary. Continuous PAP should be trialed first, during the in-laboratory study; bilevel PAP is only required if hypoventilation persists despite treatment of the obstruction with CPAP. She is 175 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 108 kg (238 lb); BMI is 37 kg/m2. Her pulse is 74/min, and her blood pressure is 141/88 mm Hg. Neck circumference is 44 cm. Results of polysomnography confirm the diagnosis. In addition to recommending weight loss and adequate sleep hygiene, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in treatment?

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl has been having behavioral problems in her pre-kindergarten class during the past 5 months. The teacher has expressed concern to the mother about attention deficit-hyperactivity disorder, citing the girl’s irritability, inability to finish tasks, tendency to talk during quiet time, and fights with other children. The girl is growing and developing normally. She sleeps an average of 11 hours a night and occasionally snores. She reports early morning headaches. Her blood pressure is in the 99th percentile for age, sex, and height. She has enlarged tonsils, normal nasal turbinates, and normal tympanic membranes. The remainder of the examination is normal. Which one of the following referrals is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient’s history, constellation of symptoms, and physical findings all suggest obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), a disorder characterized by episodes of partial or complete obstruction of the upper airway during sleep. The presenting symptoms of OSA in children often include behavioral problems, learning difficulties, snoring, sweating at night, and nocturnal enuresis. A history of persistent snoring or significant pauses in breathing during sleep can often be elicited from the child’s parents, as in this case. Polysomnography is the gold-standard test for diagnosis of OSA, and adenotonsillectomy is the first-line treatment in this age group. A referral to otolaryngology would therefore be appropriate for this patient.

Key learning point: A child presenting with nightly snoring and hyperactivity symptoms should be evaluated for obstructive sleep apnea.

B) INCORRECT:

A neurology referral is not indicated for this patient, whose headaches are more likely to be secondary to OSA.

C) INCORRECT:

A nephrology referral would be indicated if the child’s hypertension persisted despite treatment of OSA, but it would not be indicated at this time.

D) INCORRECT:

Child protective services should be contacted in cases of suspected abuse. Although behavioral problems can be a sign of abuse in young children, it is less likely in this case given the patient's constellation of symptoms and the absence of bruises or limb pain.

E) INCORRECT:

Referring this patient to child psychiatry to evaluate for attention deficit-hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) without first investigating for OSA would be inappropriate. Patients with OSA are often misdiagnosed as having ADHD and therefore remain untreated. Untreated OSA is associated with significant morbidity, including neurocognitive impairment, behavioral problems, failure to thrive, hypertension, cardiac dysfunction, and systemic inflammation.

questions.text: A 52-year-old obese man snores loudly and has daytime sleepiness. Polysomnography confirms moderate obstructive sleep apnea. What is the most appropriate first-line treatment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral mandibular advancement devices reposition the mandible to maintain airway patency and are used in mild to moderate obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) when CPAP is contraindicated or intolerable. They are less effective in obesity and moderate OSA compared to CPAP.

B) INCORRECT:

Uvulopalatopharyngoplasty (UPPP) is a surgical option for severe or refractory obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) with anatomical obstruction. For moderate OSA, especially in obesity, noninvasive treatments like CPAP are prioritized due to their efficacy and lower risk of complications.

C) INCORRECT:

Positional therapy is effective for positional obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), where apneic events are reduced in non-supine positions. However, in moderate OSA, especially with obesity, airway collapse is not solely positional. CPAP is preferred for consistent airway support.

D) CORRECT:

Continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) therapy is the first-line treatment for moderate to severe obstructive sleep apnea (OSA). CPAP delivers a constant stream of pressurized air, acting as a pneumatic splint to keep the upper airway open, preventing collapse during sleep. This improves oxygenation and reduces apneic episodes, alleviating symptoms like daytime sleepiness. CPAP also has cardiovascular benefits, reducing risks associated with untreated OSA, such as hypertension and arrhythmias.

Key learning point: Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP) is the most effective treatment for adults with obstructive sleep apnea, as it directly addresses the airway obstruction during sleep.

He denies nasal congestion or significant alcohol use. BMI is 33 kg/m², and neck circumference is 45 cm. Physical examination shows moderate oropharyngeal crowding.

Blood pressure

Which diagnostic test is the most appropriate next step to confirm the suspected diagnosis?

It does not capture nocturnal respiratory events, oxygen desaturations, or sleep architecture disturbances, which are key features of obstructive sleep apnea. Overnight polysomnography is necessary to diagnose the underlying pathophysiology responsible for the patient's symptoms.

This allows for accurate quantification of the apnea-hypopnea index, essential for determining sleep apnea severity and guiding management. The test correlates clinical symptoms, such as loud snoring and daytime somnolence, with objective sleep disturbances, confirming the diagnosis.

Nocturnal pulse oximetry screens for oxygen desaturation patterns during sleep but lacks comprehensive data for diagnosing sleep-disordered breathing. It does not record sleep stages, respiratory efforts, or arousal events, nor can it distinguish between obstructive and central apneas. Given the patient's risk factors and symptoms, accurate diagnosis requires quantifying respiratory events and assessing sleep architecture, which pulse oximetry cannot provide.

D) INCORRECT:

Arterial blood gas measurement provides information on oxygenation and ventilation but is not useful for diagnosing sleep apnea, which involves episodic upper airway obstruction during sleep. ABG analysis is typically used for acute respiratory distress or severe lung disease. In sleep apnea, intermittent hypoxemia during sleep does not result in sustained abnormalities detectable on a resting ABG sample.

A neurology referral is not indicated for this patient, whose headaches are more likely to be secondary to OSA.

D) INCORRECT:

A nephrology referral would be indicated if the child’s hypertension persisted despite treatment of OSA, but it would not be indicated at this time.

E) INCORRECT:

The provincial child welfare authority should be contacted in cases of suspected abuse. Although behavioral problems can be a sign of abuse in young children, it is less likely in this case, given the patient's constellation of symptoms.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents to the emergency department following a minor motor vehicle accident. He rear-ended another vehicle that had stopped at a red light at low-speed but has no recollection of the event: his last memory was driving towards the light, and the next was seeing his crumpled hood as the driver in front got out of his car. He lives alone and recently adopted a cat for company; he appears to be mildly allergic and has been taking loratadine daily for the last 6 weeks. He reports he has struggling with his work as a forklift truck driver because he feels so tired and forgetful, and last week was caught asleep on his machine. He reports regularly going to bed at 10pm and rising at 6am, he feels he sleeps well, but he frequently wakes up with a headache in the morning. Physical examination reveals a body mass index of 41 kg/m2, and blood pressure of 175/105 mmHg. Cardiac, respiratory, and neurological examinations are unremarkable. Which condition most likely contributed to the motor vehicle accident in this patient?

choices.text: Focal seizure with impaired awareness secondary to an intracranial space-occupying lesion

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Narcolepsy type 1 typically presents with additional symptoms including cataplexy (sudden muscle weakness triggered by emotions), sleep paralysis, and hypnagogic hallucinations. While narcolepsy can cause motor vehicle accidents, this patient obesity with large neck circumference more strongly suggests OSA. A new onset of narcolepsy is also much less common than OSA in this demographic.

B) INCORRECT:

The patient takes loratadine, which is a non-sedating antihistamine that does not typically cause drowsiness or excessive daytime sleepiness. There is no mention of other sedating medications, and medication-induced hypersomnia would not explain the hypertension or morning headaches or the specific risk factors (obesity, male gender, older age) present in this case.

C) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient's presentation is classic for obstructive sleep apnea, which is strongly associated with obesity (BMI 41), and causes morning headaches, hypertension and daytime sleepiness (due to sleep fragmentation from repetitive breathing interruptions). The motor vehicle accident risk in OSA patients is 2.5 times higher than the general population due to microsleep episodes - brief periods of involuntary sleep lasting up to 30 seconds that can occur while awake and driving. His inability to recall the accident and history of falling asleep at work are consistent with these microsleep episodes.

D) INCORRECT:

While this patient's loss of memory surrounding the accident and morning headaches could theoretically suggest focal seizures with impaired awareness from an intracranial mass, several factors make this unlikely. Seizures are usually followed by a postictal period with confusion, whereas this patient reports only a brief loss of awareness. Additionally, space-occupying lesions causing seizures usually present with focal neurological deficits, progressive neurological symptoms, or signs of increased intracranial pressure, none of which are evident here. His pattern of chronic daytime sleepiness, obesity, and hypertension is much more consistent with a sleep disorder than a structural brain lesion.

E) INCORRECT:

Central sleep apnea can cause excessive daytime sleepiness, but it is typically associated with heart failure, CNS disorders, or opioid use (none of which this patient has). This patient does, however, have multiple risk factors for obstructive sleep apnea (obesity, male gender, older age). Central sleep apnea is also much less common than obstructive sleep apnea.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for worsening shortness of breath and bilateral leg swelling over the past week. He reports significant daytime sleepiness, and his partner notes loud snoring with gasping episodes at night. BMI is 44 kg/m². His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 110/min, and respirations are 24/min. Oxygen saturation is 90% on room air. Examination shows jugular venous distention, a loud P2 heart sound, and 3+ pitting edema to the knees. Laboratory studies show a serum bicarbonate of 34 mEq/L. An ECG shows right axis deviation. Which of the following studies is most likely to confirm the underlying cause of this patient's presentation?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation is classic for obesity hypoventilation syndrome (OHS) leading to cor pulmonale. The underlying cause is chronic alveolar hypoventilation. The diagnosis of OHS requires demonstrating daytime hypercapnia (PaCO2 > 45 mm Hg) in an obese individual. An arterial blood gas analysis is the gold standard test to confirm this. The analysis will show an elevated PaCO2 and a low pH (respiratory acidosis), along with an elevated bicarbonate level, which reflects renal metabolic compensation for the chronic respiratory acidosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Polysomnography is the gold standard for diagnosing sleep-disordered breathing, such as obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), which this patient's history strongly suggests. Although over 90% of patients with obesity hypoventilation syndrome (OHS) also have OSA, polysomnography diagnoses the sleep disorder, not the daytime hypercapnia that defines OHS. A patient can have severe OSA without having OHS.

C) INCORRECT:

A transthoracic echocardiogram would be useful for evaluating the structure and function of the right heart. Given this patient's jugular venous distention, loud P2, and peripheral edema, the test would likely confirm the presence of right ventricular hypertrophy and pulmonary hypertension. However, this test identifies the consequences of the underlying disease (cor pulmonale), not the root cause, which is chronic hypoventilation.

D) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary function tests (PFTs) are often performed in the workup of obesity hypoventilation syndrome (OHS) to rule out other causes of hypoventilation, such as severe chronic obstructive pulmonary disease or interstitial lung disease. In OHS, PFTs may show a restrictive pattern due to the patient's obesity, but they can also be normal. PFTs do not directly measure arterial carbon dioxide levels and therefore cannot confirm the diagnosis of OHS.

E) INCORRECT:

A ventilation-perfusion scan is primarily used to evaluate for pulmonary embolism (PE). Although PE can cause acute dyspnea and signs of right heart strain, this patient's chronic history of sleep-disordered breathing and obesity makes obesity hypoventilation syndrome a much more likely cause of his presentation.
questions.hint: The definitive diagnosis of the underlying syndrome requires confirmation of daytime hypercapnia.
